title: Bengaluru: Police join protest rally of parents for children's safety in schools : Karnataka, News - India Today
text:
Karnataka Bengaluru: Police join protest rally of parents for children's safety in schools The protest rally was to taken out to express solidarity with the parents, whose children were sexually assaulted. The victims are all in the age group of 2.5 to 3.5 years. The protesters demanded a fast-paced probe into the incident and speedy trial. Nolan Pinto | Edited by Prabhash K Dutta A + A - 
Nine days after the arrest of the accused in child molestation case in Bengaluru, hundreds of parents today took out a peaceful protest rally in the city. 
The parents did not shout slogans. They just held placards and protest bands as they demanded safedy of children in the schools of Bengaluru. 
Sizeable police presence was there during the protest rally but the police officials surprised the protesting parents by joining the rally holding placards and wearing blue ribbons. 
Dressed in black and wearing blue ribbons, the protesters gathered at a cricket ground behind the HAL police station. 
READ| Bengaluru play school horror: Spate of FIRs reveal many other kids sexually assaulted by same man PARENTS' PROTEST IN BENGALURU: THINGS TO KNOW The protest rally was to taken out to express solidarity with the parents, whose children were sexually assaulted. The victims are all in the age group of 2.5 to 3.5 years. The protesters demanded a fast-paced probe into the incident and speedy trial. Incidentally, the police officials, who joined the protesters agreed with the demands of the parents for speedy justice to the victims. DCPof Whitefield Division M Narayana, ACP (East) Hemant Nimbalkar were among the senior police officials present in the protest rally expressing solidarity with the parents. India Today spoke to the mother of one of the victims who had participated in the protest. She said that her family had to run from pillar to post to get the FIR registered with the police. But, she is relieved now that the police are ready to extend help, she said. Victim's mother is worried about the round of questioning the little kid would have to go through during police probe and also during court trial. "We have been reassured twice. But, we now need action on ground. We are happy that they are showing the much needed focus,' she said. "We need to make them responsible for what happened or else others will feel. Well yes, we have strict guidelines but all these guidelines have loopholes and they can walk free," she said expressing her fears. Many parents expressed satisfaction that Chief Minister Siddaramaiah tweeted about the child abuse incident yesterday. They believe that Siddaramaiah's tweet will change the attitude of government officials including the police in dealing with such cases. Major Aditi (Retd), who played an active role in providing moral support to the aggrieved parents, said that the top cops coming to the protest site and addressing the parents is a welcome move. "They did a good gesture by joining the parents in this peaceful protest and we would like this to continue henceforth," she told India Today. Speaking to India Today, ACP Nimbalkar said there are some doubts in the minds of parents and the police are trying to clear them regarding the investigation and procedures being followed. Nimbalkar also said the police are with the parents on child safety issue and will make sure the investigation is complete at the earliest. "We will see that a logical end is given to the case at the earliest," he said.
